articles.headline: The End of the Affair? Not for Eric Schmidt.
articles.snippet: While Mr. Schmidt was chief executive of Google, he had an extramarital relationship with Marcy Simon, a public relations executive. A decade after they split, things are still messy.
articles.abstract: While Mr. Schmidt was chief executive of Google, he had an extramarital relationship with Marcy Simon, a public relations executive. A decade after they split, things are still messy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Eric Schmidt was the chief executive of Google in the mid-2000s, he dated Marcy Simon, a New York-based public relations executive. Both were married to other people at the time.

articles.headline: This Soccer Player Wanted to Wear Her Hijab on the Field. France Wouldn’t Let Her.
articles.snippet: Lina Boussaha joined a team in Saudi Arabia so she could wear her head scarf while playing the sport she calls “a part of my soul.”
articles.abstract: Lina Boussaha joined a team in Saudi Arabia so she could wear her head scarf while playing the sport she calls “a part of my soul.”
articles.lead_paragraph: During Ramadan, as her family fasted and prayed, Lina Boussaha, a professional soccer player, eagerly tore open a package in her bedroom in France. Inside were two head scarves she had ordered, labeled Nike, and marketed as a symbol of empowerment for Muslim women in sports.
articles.byline: By Sarah Hurtes and Iman Al-Dabbagh

articles.headline: A Money Guru Bet Big on a Very Long Life. Then He Got Cancer.
articles.snippet: Jonathan Clements, a longtime personal finance columnist for The Wall Street Journal, has a lot of savings. He’s not mad that a fatal illness will keep him from spending it.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Clements, a longtime personal finance columnist for The Wall Street Journal, has a lot of savings. He’s not mad that a fatal illness will keep him from spending it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most of us will live an amazingly long life and should not worry so much about dying young.

articles.headline: How Hamas Is Fighting in Gaza: Tunnels, Traps and Ambushes
articles.snippet: Hamas overwhelmed Israel’s border in October with a coordinated, large-scale maneuver before committing atrocities. Now, it acts as a guerrilla force, its fighters often disguised as civilians.
articles.abstract: Hamas overwhelmed Israel’s border in October with a coordinated, large-scale maneuver before committing atrocities. Now, it acts as a guerrilla force, its fighters often disguised as civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: They hide under residential neighborhoods, storing their weapons in miles of tunnels and in houses, mosques, sofas — even a child’s bedroom — blurring the boundary between civilians and combatants.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Sella and Iyad Abuheweila

articles.headline: Is There a Future in the Doomsday Economy?
articles.snippet: With Fortitude Ranch, the entrepreneur Drew Miller is betting on franchised timeshares for people who are worried about the end of the world.
articles.abstract: With Fortitude Ranch, the entrepreneur Drew Miller is betting on franchised timeshares for people who are worried about the end of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to surviving the apocalypse, you could do a lot worse than the West Virginia branch of Fortitude Ranch, a constellation of five survivalist compounds across the United States and one of a growing number of businesses aiming to seize on Americans’ deepening anxieties about the future.
articles.byline: By Alexander Nazaryan and Emily Najera

articles.headline: How Janet Yellen Became an Unlikely Culinary Diplomat
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary views food as a way to connect, and her dining decisions have become the subject of global intrigue.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary views food as a way to connect, and her dining decisions have become the subject of global intrigue.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was mayonnaise mixed with ants at a gastronomic taqueria in Mexico City. The garlic at a Persian restaurant in Frankfurt was aged 25 years. And, yes, the magic mushrooms in Beijing were hallucinogenic.

articles.headline: Unbowed by Jan. 6 Charges, Republicans Pursue Plans to Contest a Trump Defeat
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s allies are preparing to try to short-circuit the election system, if he does not win.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s allies are preparing to try to short-circuit the election system, if he does not win.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican Party and its conservative allies are engaged in an unprecedented legal campaign targeting the American voting system. Their wide-ranging and methodical effort is laying the groundwork to contest an election that they argue, falsely, is already being rigged against former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Israel Launches Major Attack Against a Senior Hamas Commander
articles.snippet: The target, Muhammad Deif, was an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks and has been the object of repeated Israeli assassination attempts over decades.
articles.abstract: The target, Muhammad Deif, was an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks and has been the object of repeated Israeli assassination attempts over decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel conducted a major airstrike in southern Gaza on Saturday morning that it said had targeted a top Hamas military commander who is considered one of the architects of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, according to six senior Israeli officials.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Here’s What Is Known About the Suspect Who Tried to Assassinate Trump
articles.snippet: Authorities identified the gunman as a 20-year-old man from Bethel Park, Pa., a town about an hour’s drive from the site of the shooting.
articles.abstract: Authorities identified the gunman as a 20-year-old man from Bethel Park, Pa., a town about an hour’s drive from the site of the shooting.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Jack Healy, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Electric Vehicles May Become Harder to Rent
articles.snippet: Rental car firms are offering temporary deals on electric cars, which they are selling after they lost value more quickly than expected.
articles.abstract: Rental car firms are offering temporary deals on electric cars, which they are selling after they lost value more quickly than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’ve been wanting to try an electric vehicle, renting can be an affordable option. But finding one may soon become much more difficult.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Dionne Searcey

articles.headline: A Father’s Last Act: Shielding His Family From Gunshots
articles.snippet: Relatives and friends described Corey Comperatore, who was fatally shot at a Trump rally, as a devoted father who served as a volunteer firefighter and loved to fish.
articles.abstract: Relatives and friends described Corey Comperatore, who was fatally shot at a Trump rally, as a devoted father who served as a volunteer firefighter and loved to fish.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corey Comperatore, 50, was a family man who loved to fish. He worked at a plastics manufacturing company, volunteered as a firefighter and went to church.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Isabelle Taft, Christina Morales and Brian Conway

articles.headline: An Assassination Attempt That Seems Likely to Tear America Further Apart
articles.snippet: The attack on former President Donald J. Trump comes at a time when the United States is already polarized along ideological and cultural lines and is split, it often seems, into two realities.
articles.abstract: The attack on former President Donald J. Trump comes at a time when the United States is already polarized along ideological and cultural lines and is split, it often seems, into two realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the Trump assassination attempt.

articles.headline: Secret Service Under Scrutiny After Assassination Attempt on Trump
articles.snippet: President Biden calls for a review of the protective agency’s actions after the attack, which left an audience member dead and two critically wounded.
articles.abstract: President Biden calls for a review of the protective agency’s actions after the attack, which left an audience member dead and two critically wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Sunday called for an “independent review” of security measures before and after the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump, while directing the Secret Service to review all of its security measures for the Republican National Convention this week.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, David A. Fahrenthold, Hamed Aleaziz and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: China Is Holding a Major Meeting on the Economy That You Can’t Watch
articles.snippet: President Xi Jinping is presiding over a conclave to draft a new economic program. The stakes are high, but expectations for big changes are modest.
articles.abstract: President Xi Jinping is presiding over a conclave to draft a new economic program. The stakes are high, but expectations for big changes are modest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, and 370 or so other Communist Party officials are meeting in Beijing this week, away from the public eye, to review a plan intended to shake the world’s second-biggest economy out of its malaise.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: By Burning Down Buildings, Insurers Want to Change How They’re Built
articles.snippet: Property insurers are trying to force changes in construction standards that they say are necessary to protect against wildfires.
articles.abstract: Property insurers are trying to force changes in construction standards that they say are necessary to protect against wildfires.
articles.lead_paragraph: The insurance industry is setting homes on fire — just to make a point.

articles.headline: The Book Bag That Binds Japanese Society
articles.snippet: No rule requires Japan’s elementary school students to wear the boxy, bulky backpack known as the randoseru. But for nearly 150 years, nearly all of them have.
articles.abstract: No rule requires Japan’s elementary school students to wear the boxy, bulky backpack known as the randoseru. But for nearly 150 years, nearly all of them have.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Japan, cultural expectations are repeatedly drilled into children at school and at home, with peer pressure playing as powerful a role as any particular authority or law. On the surface, at least, that can help Japanese society run smoothly.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Noriko Hayashi

articles.headline: Judge Dismisses Classified Documents Case Against Trump
articles.snippet: Judge Aileen Cannon ruled that the entire case should be thrown out because the appointment of the special counsel who brought the case, Jack Smith, had violated the Constitution. Mr. Smith’s office said he would appeal.
articles.abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon ruled that the entire case should be thrown out because the appointment of the special counsel who brought the case, Jack Smith, had violated the Constitution. Mr. Smith’s office said he would appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case threw out all of the charges against him on Monday, ruling that Jack Smith, the special counsel who filed the indictment, had been given his job in violation of the Constitution.

articles.headline: Caterpillar Factory in Mexico Draws Complaint of Labor Abuses
articles.snippet: The Biden administration declined to pursue a union complaint of labor abuses in Mexico, raising new concerns about offshoring.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration declined to pursue a union complaint of labor abuses in Mexico, raising new concerns about offshoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, as major manufacturers have announced plans to ramp up production in Mexico, labor unions have raised concerns that American jobs will be sent abroad.

articles.headline: Trading Free-Market Ideals for Protectionism, G.O.P. Goes Full Trump
articles.snippet: The Republican Party is rejecting elite economic ideas in a bid for blue-collar votes, abandoning long-held free-market principles in the process.
articles.abstract: The Republican Party is rejecting elite economic ideas in a bid for blue-collar votes, abandoning long-held free-market principles in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidency was a major turn away from the Republican Party’s long embrace of free-market economics. If the Republican platform is any indication, a second Trump term would be a near-complete abandonment.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
